title: Wachspress Geometry
text:
Wachspress Geometry is a young subject in the intersection of geometry, combinatorics and algebra, and at the core of my DFG grant “Wachspress Coordinates - a Bridge betwen Algebra, Geometry and Combinatorics”.
Wachspress Geometry has a dual nature:

it is the study of the so-called Wachspress objects, a family of constructions on convex polytopes.
it is one of the best understood instance of Positive Geometry.

text:

polyhedral combinatorics and geometry,
graph theory (spectral, algebraic, geometric and topological),
rigidity theory, geometric constraint system and real algebraic geometry,
low-dimensional topology (knot theory, embeddings and embeddability of graphs and complexes, …)
symmetries of discrete and geometric objects,
finite group theory and real representation theory,
algebraic combinatorics (association schemes, distance regular graphs, codes …),
convex geometry,
random structures and graph limits,
discrete dynamical systems, …

My current main project is on Wachspress Geometry.

title: Martin Winter
text:
Martin Winter, PhD  martin.h.winter@warwick.ac.uk


This website is currently under construction. For my previous website at the University of Warwick, click here.


I am a mathematician and Dirichlet fellow at TU Berlin. My main mathematical interest is Geometry in its various forms, in particular, discrete, algebraic, convex and computational geometry, also touching on many aspects of graph theory, topology and representation theory. I am often working with polytopes and simplicial complexes, both in geometric and combinatorial contexts. Most recently I am studying the Wachspress Geometry of convex polytopes.
I am principal investigator in the priority program “Combinatorial Synergies”. My project “Wachspress Coordinates - a Bridge between Algebra, Geometry and Combinatorics” will be conducted at the Max-Planck-Institute for Mathematics in the Sciences in Leipzig (Germany), starting April 2025.

title: The non-symmetric Mahler conjecture
text:
The Mahler conjecture is usually stated for centrally symmetric convex bodies. Its non-symmetric version seems however equally interesting and inaccessible. As it turns out, the non-symmetric version has a neat formulation in terms of volume (not Mahler volume) of self-polar bodies.

Given a centrally symmetric convex body \(B\subset\Bbb R^n\) (which we shall assume means \(-B=B\)), Kurt Mahler defined the following linearly invariant “notion of volume” – now known as the Mahler volume:
\[
M(B):=\operatorname{vol}(B)\cdot\operatorname{vol}(B^\circ).
\]
Here \(B^\circ:=\{y\in\Bbb R^n\mid \langle x,y\rangle\le 1\text{ for all }x\in B\}\) denotes the polar dual of \(B\). This quantity is maximized for the sphere (which is known as the Santaó inequality`). Mahler conjectured that it is minimized for the cube: for every centrally symmetric convex body \(B\subset\Bbb R^n\) holds
\[M(B)\ge M(\text{$n$-cube}) = \frac{4^n}{n!}.\]
This is known as the Mahler conjecture.
This is known as the Mahler conjecture. This problem is excruciatingly hard, and a lot of things have been written on it. Here you can find a blog post by Terry Tao who already tells you most of it. He states that the problem might be so hard because there is not a single minimizer, but many, and it is hard to imagine a process that converges to exactly those. I am sceptical about this precise phrasing, because the Mahler conjecture has a non-centrallsy symmetric counterpart, which is equially widely open.
I do not want to repeat what has been written on the conjecture by others. I just want to contribute two smaller details.
The following is an equivalent formulation of the non-symmetric Mahler conjecture:


Conjecture.  The simplex has the smallest volume among all self-polar polytopes.

title: Inscribed zonotopes
text:
Recall that a zonotope is a polytope all whose faces are centrally symmetric. Equivalently (though not trivially so) zonotopes can be defined as Minkowski sums of line segments.
A polytope is inscribed if all its vertices lie on a sphere.
Both zonotopes and inscribed polytopes are abundant, but it turns out that asking for both at the same time is surprisingly restrictive. In fact, only 17 are known in dimension three (+ an infinite family of prisms), yet we can’t even show that there are finitely many (ignoring the prisms). But let’s move slowly.
Some examples come to mind easily: the cube, prisms, and perhaps even the permutahedron. All those actually share a property much stronger than being inscribed: they are vertex-transitive, that is, their orthogonal symmetry group acts transitively on the vertices.
…
In [1] I showed the vertex those are exactly the \(\Gamma\)-permutahedra, where \(\Gamma\) is a finite reflection group.
A vertex-transitive zonotope might have realizations that are inscribed but not vertex-transitive. For example, the \(A_3\)-zonotope can be realized as an inscribed zonotope with any of the following generators:
\[\alpha_i\alpha_j (\alpha_i e_j-\alpha_j e_i)\]
In contrast, the \(H_3\)-zonotope can be realized as an inscribed zonotope in exactly one way, which is then vertex-transitive.
Sanyal and Manecke noted that the projection of an isncribed zonotope along an edge direction yields again an inscribed zonotope. Starting from higher-dimensional \(\Gamma\)-permutahedra this gives rise to many inscribed zonotopes of new combinatorial types. I like to call them quasi-permutahedra. All in all they found 17 combinatorial types for which they generated the graphics below.
They also gave the following diagram showing the realtios between the different quasi-permutahedra.
It should be noted that all inscribed zonotopes are simple, that is, their graph is regular and the degree is exactly the dimension. As such, the hyperplane arrangement that corresponds the the zonotope (i.e. the arrangement whose normal vectors are the edge directions) is simplicial. Simplicial hyperplane arrangements are a beast on their own and form their own exclusive club. The “trivial” examples are the reflection arrangements. The most up-to-date list in dimension three is due to Grünbaum and Cuntz and list 93 arrangements + 3 infinite families. Sanyal and Manecke verified that only the quasi-reflection arrangements (the ones obtained by restriction of a reflection arrangements to a hyperplane) lead to inscribed zonotopes (on the way they verified that all the known arrangements are projectively unique!). They did however find that some arrangements lead to strange “zonotope-like” objects that are inscribed not in a sphere, but a different quadric!

title: Embedding 2-complexes in \(\Bbb R^4\)
text:
A 2-dimensional CW-complex is a graph with some 2-dimensional disks attached. Each such complex embeds in 5-dimensional Euclidean space, but not neccessarily in 4-dimensional space, and deciding whether it embeds in \(\Bbb R^4\) is a very hard problem.
Here are some examples and counterexamples:

\(\mathcal K_6\) is the complex obtained from the complete graph \(K_6\) by attaching a 2-cell along each triangle. This complex embedds in \(\Bbb R^4\). One way to see this is to consider a Schlegel diagram of a 5-dimensional simplex (whose edge graph is \(K_6\)); its 2-skeleton gives the desired embedding.
\(\mathcal K_7\) (defined like \(\mathcal K_6\) but from \(K_7\)) does not embed.
if we remove a single 2-cell from \(\mathcal K_7\), it does embed.
starting from \(K_5\) and adding three cones over it yields a classically non-embeddable complex.



Conjecture. If \(X_\circ\) embeds then the following are equivalent:


\(X_\bullet\) embeds.


\(X_\star\) embeds.

title: Two additions to the Mahler conjecture
text:
Given a centrally symmetric convex body \(B\subset\Bbb R^n\) (which we shall assume means \(-B=B\)), Mahler defined the following linearly invariant “notion of volume” – the Mahler volume:
\[
M(B):=\operatorname{vol}(B)\cdot\operatorname{vol}(B^\circ),
\]
where \(B^\circ:=\{y\in\Bbb R^n\mid \langle x,y\rangle\le 1\text{ for all }x\in B\}\) denotes the polar dual of \(B\). He then conjectured that
\[M(P)\ge M(\text{$d$-cube}) = \frac{4^d}{d!}.\]
This is known as the Mahler conjecture. This problem is excruciatingly hard, and a lot of things have been written on it. Here you can find a blog article by Terry Tao. He states that the problem might be so hard because there is not a single minimizer, but many, and it is hard to imagine a process that converges to exactly those. I am sceptical about this precise phrasing, because the Mahler conjecture has a non-centrallsy symmetric counterpart, which is equially widely open.
I do not want to repeat what has been written on the conjecture by others. I just want to contribute two smaller details.

Non-symmetric Mahler and self-polar polytopes
The non-symmetric Mahler conjecture has


Mahler for coordinate-symmetric polytopes
Here I simply want to include a very beautiful and very magic proof of the Mahler conjecture for so-called coordinate-symmetric (or unconditional) polytopes.
A convex body \(B\subset\Bbb R^n\) is coordinate-symmetric if it is invariant under reflection on every coordinate hyperplane \(H_i:=\{x_i=0\}\).  This class of convex bodies is in the literature better known as unconditional bodies. I am unsure about the origin of this term, and I tend to dislike it since it is seems the opposite of self-explanatory.
A coordinate-symmetric corner is the restriction of a coordinate symmetric body to the positive orthant \(\Bbb R_+:=\{(x_1,...,x_n)\in\Bbb R^n\mid x_i\ge 0\}\). Since every coordinate-symmetric body consists of \(2^n\) coordinate-symmetric corners, one can proof their Mahler conjecture by proving the following:
The statement of the Mahler conjecture for antiblocking polytopes reduces to
\[M_+(P_+):=\operatorname{vol}(P_+)\cdot\operatorname{vol}(P_+^*) \ge 1/d!\]
A fairly short inductive proof goes as follows: let \(P_i:=P_+\cap\{x_i=0\}\) and \(P_i^*:=P_+^*\cap \{x_i=0\}\), which are antiblocking. Define vectors \(v,v^*\in\Bbb R^d\) by
\[ v_i := \frac{\operatorname{vol}_{d-1}(P_i)}{d \operatorname{vol}_{d}(P_+)},\quad\; v_i^* := \frac{\operatorname{vol}_{d-1}(P_i^*)}{d \operatorname{vol}_{d}(P_+^*)}\]
For a point \(x\in \Bbb R_+^d\) the inner product \(\langle x,v\rangle\) evaluates to
\[
\langle x,v\rangle
= \sum_{i=1}^d x_i\frac{\operatorname{vol}_{d-1}(P_i)}{d \operatorname{vol}_d(P_+)}
= \frac1{\operatorname{vol}_{d}(P_+)} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^d \underbrace{\tfrac1d{x_i \operatorname{vol}_{d-1}(P_i)}}_{\operatorname{vol}_d(C_i)},
\]
where \(C_i\) is the cone with base face \(P_i\) and cone point \(x\). If \(x\in P_+\) then the cones \(C_i\) have disjoint interiors and are contained in \(P_+\). In particular, the sum of their volumes is bounded by \(\operatorname{vol}_d(P_+)\). Therefore \(\langle x,v\rangle \le 1\) for all \(x\in P_+\), and hence \(v\in P_+^*\). By an analogous argument holds \(v^*\in P_+\). In particular,
\[
\begin{align}
1\ge &\langle v,v^*\rangle
=  \sum_{i=1}^d \frac{\operatorname{vol}_{d-1}(P_i)\operatorname{vol}_{d-1}(P_i^*)}{d^2\operatorname{vol}_d(P_+)\operatorname{vol}_d(P_+^*)}
= \sum_{i=1}^d \frac{M_+(P_i)}{d^2M_+(P_+)}.
\end{align}
\]
By rearranging and applying the induction hypothesis \(M_+(P_i)\ge 1/(d-1)!\) we conclude
\[
M_+(P_+) \ge \frac1{d^2} \sum_{i=1}^d M_+(P_i) \ge \frac1{d^2} \cdot\frac{d}{(d-1)!} = \frac1{d!}.
\]
This prove was first shown to me by Raman Sanyal. But it goes back to [1]. An earlier but much more involved proof can be found in [1].

title: Packing colorings and the mystery threshold 1.264499…
text:
In a proper coloring of a graph any two vertices of the same color must be at distance at least two. In a packing coloring more general distance constraints can hold. For example, one might ask that any two vertices with the \(i\)-th color \(c_i\) are at distance \(>i\). Here is a packing coloring of the infinite path \(P_\infty\) that is periodic in both directions:
\[
\dots
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{ForestGreen}3}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{ForestGreen}3}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\dots
\]
It is explicitly possible to have different colors with the same distance constraints, so here are two examples of this:
\[
\dots
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}1}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\dots
\qquad
\dots
\rlap{\color{red}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{ForestGreen}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{red}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{blue}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\rlap{\color{ForestGreen}2}\raise{-1pt}\_\,
\dots
\]
For a general packing coloring we fix a pallette \(\boldsymbol c\), that is, a finite or infinite sequence \(c_1\le c_2\le c_3\le\dots\) of natural numbers (which we call colors). We say that a graph \(G\) has a (packing) coloring using the pallette \(\boldsymbol c\) if it can be colored using finitely many of the colors, so that any two vertices of color \(c_i\) have distance \(>c_i\).
Note that a color \(c_i\) can appear at most at every \((c_i+1)\)-th vertex, hence, can have an asymptotic density of at most \((c_i+1)^{-1}\). We define the density of a pallette to be:
\[\delta(\boldsymbol c) := \sum_i \frac1{c_i+1}.\]
Since a proper packing coloring has asymptotic density exactly 1, we see that \(\delta(\boldsymbol c)<1\) implies that \(\boldsymbol c\) does not packing color.
If \(\delta(\boldsymbol c)<1\), the pallette cannot color. In contrast, if \(\delta(\boldsymbol c)>2\), then the pallette does color. Somewhere in between there is a number \(\zeta\) so that whenever \(\delta(\boldsymbol c)>\zeta\), then \(\boldsymbol c\) colors. We conjecture
\[\zeta=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \frac1{2^i+1} \approx 1.264499...\;.\]

title: Lecture – Polytope Theory
text:
I taught this TCC course on “Polytope Theory” starting from October 10th 2022 for 8 weeks. Due to the nature of TCC courses (being streamed to several universities) this was an online course taught via MS Teams.

Introduction
Polytope Theory is the study of (convex) polytopes, the generalization of polygons (2D) and polyhedra (3D) to general dimension. Besides their geometric nature as convex sets, polytopes possess a rich combinatorial structure, making them exceptionally accessible by combinatorial techniques. The study of polytopes reaches from the antiquity (starting from the Platonic solids), over the 19th/20th century (understanding polytopes in 3D and initializing the study of polytopes in dimension \(\ge 3\)), until today, where we understand that the richness of polytopal phenomena starts in dimension 4 and which led to findings such as universality. The subject has shown proximity to algebraic geometry, representation theory, analysis, optimization and many more.


Scope
In this course I aimed to give an overview of this very diverse subject and cover selected topics with focus towards research and open questions. I tried to cover the following, though not everything made it into the final course:


realization spaces and universality


Gale duality and enumeration of combinatorial types


face numbers, Dehn-Sommerville equations and the Upper Bound Theorem


reconstruction from the edge graph


spectral theory of polytopes, expansion and Izmestiev’s Theorem


geometry and combinatorics of 3-dimensional polytopes


inscribability and related geometric constraints


symmetry properties of polytopes


zonotopes


the polytope algebra




Prerequisites
Besides an elementary geometric understanding, the prerequisites are minimal:


linear algebra


elementary graph theory: basic definitions (sub-graph, vertex degree, bipartite graph), connectivity, handshaking lemma, planar graphs, etc


basic convex geometry: convex sets and cones, hyperplanes, some central theorems (Carathéodory’s theorem, hyperplane separation theorem) though we will give ample reminders for these


basic combinatorics: mostly some counting coefficients


basics of partially ordered sets, lattices, etc


Not strictly necessary, but a background in any of the following will provide motivation and can help the understanding at some points: linear/convex optimization, algebraic topology, real representation theory of finite groups.


Literature


B. Grünbaum, “Convex Polytopes” (a bit older, but with all the essentials)


G. Ziegler, “Lectures on Polytopes” (modern, more focused on combinatorial aspects in the later chapters)


A. Brøndsted, “An Introduction to Convex Polytopes”


I. Pak, “Lectures on Discrete and Polyhedral Geometry” (not specific to polytopes, but contains many neat proofs; freely available)




Course notes
These course notes were created during each lecture. I am aware that there is the occasional typo, but overall they are correct.


 Lecture 1 (10/10/2022) Introduction (overview, motivation, applications), definition of polytope, V-polytopes, H-polytopes, Minkowski-Weyl theorem


 Lecture 2 (17/10/2022)Polar duals, faces and facets, face lattice, vertex figures


 Lecture 3 (24/10/2022)3-polytopes, edge-graphs, Steintz’ theorem, Balinski’s theorem, simple/simplicial polytopes, neighborly polytopes, cyclic polytopes, Gale’s evenness criterion, Kalai’s simple way to tell a simple polytope from its graph


 Lecture 4 (31/10/2022)Counting faces, Euler’s polyhedral formula + Euler Poincaré identity, Dehn-Sommerville equations, upper bound theorem, g-theorem


 Lecture 5 (07/11/2022)Polytopal complexes, shellability, line/linear shelling, Schlegel diagrams, abstract polytopal/simplicial complexes


 Lecture 6 (14/11/2022)Gale duality (linear/affine), spherical Gale diagrams, classifying small polytopes (d+1, d+2, d+3 vertices)


 Lecture 7 (21/11/2022) + GeoGebra files: addition, multiplication, squaring, golden ratio Realization spaces, centered realization space, (affine) Gale diagrams, point-line arrangements, Mnëv’s universality theorem, universality of 4-polytopes, non-rational polytopes



 Lecture 8 (28/11/2022)Selection of research directions in polytope theory
